comments:
I'm using Eclipse M6, stable build 1218, and Sun JDK 1.4.2_02.

Test case:

1. Install Eclipse M6 (e.g. unzip it to C:\eclipse).
2. Launch Eclipse.
3. Help->Software Updates->Find and Install...
4. Install CDT 2.0 (http://update.eclipse.org/tools/cdt/updates/builds/2.0)
5. After the installation is complete, close Eclipse.
6. Open Windows Explorer and rename C:\eclipse to C:\eclipseM6
7. Try launching eclipse.  It will not start.  The .log file contents are 
below.

Renaming C:\eclipseM6 to C:\eclipse does not fix the problem.

This seems odd, but we'll take a look. This area is undergoing lots of changes 
right now, so you may expect a bit of shakiness until M7.
*** Bug 50501 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I just realized that "eclipse" name for the directory is "API" and cannot be 
changed. As such, I will return the bug as invalid. You could alwasy unzip the 
entire driver under c:\eclipseM6 (and get c:\eclipseM6\eclipse as the install 
directory).
Renaming the directory back to c:\eclipse is happening after an invalid 
operation, so it is not guaranteed to get you in the original state.

How come when I changed the directory name "eclipse" to something else, I did 
NOT get this message?

"Renaming, moving or deleting "eclipse" could not make some programs not work. 
Are you sure you want to do this?"

We should catch this because we will lose our workspace and restart over again.

Thanks.

Perhaps because Windows Explorer did not know that eclipse should not be 
renamed?

How many times do you install programs and then change the directory name? I 
bet that almost all windows programs registered in the windows registry would 
fail to work once you rename their install directory. Eclipse can actually be 
moved around, as long as you move the entire eclipse dir (including 
the "eclipse" dir itself).

Please note the following:

1. This bug did NOT exist in M5.
2. Eclipse is NOT installed in the same manner as a typical Windows 
application, unzipping a file does not constitute an installation ;)  A quick 
search of the registry does NOT reveal any Eclipse path keys either.
3. I was unable to find anything in the help documentation indicating that you 
CANNOT rename your "installation" directory.
4. This problem ONLY exists when you download something with Update Manager. 
You can rename the "installation" directory as much as you like so long as 
Update Manager is not used.
5. "Eclipse can actually be moved around" - not true, try the test case (be 
sure to use Update Manager) and move the directory, the same problem occurs.
6. This bug needs to be addressed as Eclipse cannot recover from this error.  
As such, a data integrity problem is introduced, and that is bad ;)

Thanks!

Dorian,

We just noticed some weird behavior when we are installing the CDT using the 
Update Manager in M6.  Bug 50495 shows that the CDT is disappearing (C/C++ 
perspective is not loading) after installing it using the Update Manager.

How do we want to track this?  I know there is a lot of churn going on in 
Update Manager.  Should we leave this issue open until we get M7?

Thanks.

You're trying really hard to convince us :-)
Although I don't quite buy these arguments, the only concern I have is the 
following scenario that seems be to be implied by arguments 4 and 5:

You install eclipse on c:\ as c:\eclipse. Then you use the update mgr to 
install a new feature, restart, etc. things work fine.
Then, you take the entire eclipse directory and move it to, day, d:\, as 
d:\eclipse. Now, launch eclipse again and expect it to work.
(I am assuming the workspace is located elsewhere, not in eclipse\workspace).

I don't think there is a claim anywhere that you can move eclipse 
installations (but this is nice, desirable capability), but I'd still be 
looking at the bug if the scenario above does not work.

You bet I am trying to convince you ;)

Interestingly, your scenario does work! I can even rename the installation 
directory from "eclipse" to "eclipseM6" (for example) and Eclipse.exe starts 
up with no problems. :)

Why did you clarify that the workspace had to be outside of the installation 
directory?  I ask because if the workspace is inside the installation 
directory, then Eclipse.exe crashes.

FYI: I played around a bit - it turns out that if the user does change the 
name or location of their installation directory (for whatever reason) AFTER 
using Update Manager, then they can get Eclipse.exe working again by deleting 
the ".config" directory.  After that, the user can then rename and relocate 
the installation directory at will and Eclipse.exe will no longer crash.  Is 
this really an acceptable workflow?

IMOHO, it is still worth investigating why the problem seems to be tied to 
Update Manager and why deleting the .config directory seems to fix the problem.

Thanks!

The .config directory contains configuration data such as cached bundles, etc. 
that may have absolute paths, so changing a directory name may break things.
The workspace is where plugin state data and projects go, so again, there 
could be some absolute paths in there.

I will leave the bug open for now, as we are making some changes in the config 
area, but in general, it is not expected that eclipse can just be moved 
around. The recommended way is to have fixed place for the workspace area and 
be able to install various eclipse builds without loosing any work.

The update mgr only stores relative links (as well as it can) in build 0303.
If you see any problems, please reopen.
